title: Are Bible movie adaptations sacrilegious? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sacrilegious: violation or misuse of what is regarded as sacred. Revelation 22:18,19 says, I am bearing witness to everyone who hears the words of the prophecy of this scroll: If anyone makes an addition to these things, God will add to him the plagues that are written in this scroll; 19 and if anyone takes anything away from the words of the scroll of this prophecy, God will take his portion away from the trees of life and out of the holy city, things that are written about in this scroll. There is no record of such an adulterous affair, as Moses was then married to Zipporah with two sons, who came to do God’s will to deliver God’s people from bondage. That was his assignment that God had given him through thorough training given him by God those forty years in Midian. Again, looking back at Revelation 22, there was to be no additions made to prophecies or taken away. Those who did or have done so will be dealt with. So does God believe there has been a violation or misuse of his word the Bible, then yes, they have sacrificed God’s word of authenticity for the sake of their own glory rather than God’s. Most Bible movies are not intended to offend the intended audience. That’s why they are rarely blasphemous (bad) or sacrilegious (worse). The 2014 “Noah” movie was one I heard ministers recommend against on religious grounds. Why? Appropriating a religious story to inject a radical environmentalist message was one thing. The Gnostic message in it, though, resulted in more than one minister calling it sacrilegious and blasphemous. The directors knew that and admitted it, too. “The Last Temptation of Christ” has been considered sacrilegious. It doesn’t even link to canon. Main issue for many Christians was the sexual temptation of Christ. On the flipside, “Passion of the Christ” was one ministers recommended because it was not just Biblical but moving. Because it was so good as a story and faithful to canon, it became a blockbuster. “Life of Brian” is definitely blasphemous and such on purpose, as is “Dogma”. Then again, these were comedy movies intended to offend unlike “Evan Almighty”, a modern update of “Noah”. Yet I wouldn’t call these Bible adaptations because the sheer purpose of many such works is to attack the faith for the sake of laughs or the audience that wants to mock Christians.

Only if they attempt to deliberately distort the viewer into believing that the Biblical account is not true. For the most part, big-screen Biblical epics have either been a pretty faithful retelling of some part of the Bible, or a fictional tale (best example: Ben-Hur) set in Biblical times that “fits” the Biblical narrative. The Bible doesn’t give us a lot of detail and almost none of the dialog that would have taken place during the various events in the life of Biblical characters, so the writers would have to fill in some dialog not found in the Bible itself. This might be where your question came from, with movies like “The Jesus Story” and “The Greatest Story Ever Told” that went deep into the lives of many characters besides Jesus. In these cases, they could have become sacrilegious, but didn’t, because even though they used dialog not found in the Bible, nothing in them contradicts the character of the people or the events, etc. There are exceptions to this, of course. The recent movie “Noah” starring Russel Crowe added some events and characteristics to Noah that flat-out lied about what kind of man he was. I would consider it bad enough to dub it as “sacrilegious”. There are a few other examples, but like I said, for the most part, movie adaptations of Biblical stories are just fine.

Mostly Yes, but not all. A person who wishes only to wholly re-enact a biblical story (without corrupting the biblical message) for educational purpose is not being Sacrilegious. But there are very few instances , if any , that record the Biblical message without bias of some sort of Doctrine, then it becomes a case of what the Apostle Paul calls “Another Gospel” and the consequences are the same. Some can be but the worst problem is the inaccuracy. Noah was an egregious example. Noah has the Nephilim, fallen angels, help him build the Ark, which isn’t Biblical but not ruled out either. The evil people of the region storm the ark as the rain begins to fall, whereas Noah and his family were buttoned up in the Ark long before then. Noah’s youngest Japheth, rescues a girl but Noah decrees that God intends to sweep the earth clean. In reality, the Bible account makes it clear that Noah, his sons, and their wives were on the Ark. So was there widespread outrage at the inaccuracies? No. All the outrage was directed against the idea that Mankind was being punished for despoiling the Earth. All kinds of wild inaccuracies were permissible but don’t bring environmentalism into the story.

Some of them are disgustingly inaccurate and insulting to the scriptures and the God who inspired them. Others are pretty good. If the scriptwriters and producers are determined to stick to the biblical story-line as accurately as they can, taking into account the contextual settings, then I think the resulting movie is pretty good and it can be entertaining at the same time. I think back to my schooldays when I watched those Charlton Heston movies The Exodus and The Ten Commandments and I would still enjoy watching them 60 years later. They were not entirely accurate, admittedly, but one was left with the impression that the producers respected the source material and gave it their best unbiased effort. So, making a bible-based movie is not sacrilegious if the production is done respectfully. But others, like the more recently released ‘NOAH’ are pathetic in their inaccurate and bigoted and biased way of presenting the facts as recorded in the bible. I would call such movies sacrilegious.

The movie completely twists the truth, and that is just one example of all the falsehoods found in bible movie adaptations. All bible movie adaptations are essentially evil and should not be watched. If you want to know what happened, then read the scriptures themselves. The written accounts are true.

The answer will depend upon which movie, what it says/does, and your religious view of the subject being treated in the movie. One (of many) definitions of “sacrilege” is: “an act that destroys, hurts or ruins something sacred. An example of a sacrilegious act is the burning of a cross.” (yourdictionary.com) It should be obvious that this is only a sacrilege in the opinion of someone who holds a cross as a sacred object. Probably no one except a Christian would deem that act a sacrilege. So, a depiction of a biblical story might be viewed as sacrilegious by one who disagreed with the writer/director’s interpretation of the scene(s). Many people found Mel Gibson’s “The Passion of the Christ” to be highly sacrilegious while others found it deeply moving and spiritually meaningful. Not many Christians would consider the breaking, burning, or disfiguring of a statue of Ganesh as a sacrilege, but my next-door neighbor, who is Hindu, would be appalled at such a sacrilege. So, perhaps sacrilege is in the eye of the beholder.

I think that depends on both the perspective of the viewer and what the production does with it. I am not old enough to really remember but apparently Charleston Heston played Moses in the story of the Exodus; apparently there were a surprising number of things in there that demonstrated heavy research into the commentators' statements of the unwritten story. It is hard to see fault with something like that. Conversely, if they went all Borat or Keystone Cop (which apparently a lot of early films about both native Americans or black people did) then that would be sacrilegious. It all depends on respect, I think.

A lot of them are (have you seen Noah? Christ preserve us; that thing was wild heresy). There are faithful ones, though, which I would no more consider sacrilege than I would consider one guy (correctly) telling another guy about Jesus sacrilege. It is simply another way to tell people, though movies do not have God’s promise of accuracy attached to them, as Scripture does, so make and believe with caution, knowing that these never replace Scripture.

I don’t believe so if you see movie adaptations as just another way communicating the bible story in a faithful way (to me, the word faithful describes the boundaries). I realize that the bible doesn’t always give us a lot of detail, and that a certain ‘poetic licence’ is expected ; but movie adaptations can easily become sacrilegious when the adaptation in question seeks to destroy, hurt or ruin something known to be sacred, because of a total lack of respect — too prevalent in our world as it is.
